The patient is a 67-year-old woman with chronic pancreatitis and severe acute blood loss anemia likely due to an upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient has a history of gastritis confirmed by biopsy. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) revealed a necrotic duodenal ulcer with only a slow ooze. No intervention was taken due to the tenuous appearance of the ulcer. The patient received 5 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs) and her hemoglobin concentration (Hct) is currently stable at 29%.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.3째C (101째F), heart rate of 77 beats per minute, blood pressure of 93/52 mmHg, respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on nasal cannula. The patient is alert and oriented, with no acute distress. Physical examination reveals tenderness in all four quadrants of the abdomen, right and left radial and dorsalis pedis pulses present, symmetric chest expansion, clear breath sounds, warm skin, and muscle wasting.

Laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 7.0 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin concentration of 23.0 g/dL, platelet count of 209 x 10^9/L, creatinine level of 0.9 mg/dL, glucose level of 111 mg/dL, and an international normalized ratio (INR) of 1.0. Imaging reveals evidence of old healed apical granulomatous disease and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, as well as a single cratered 2cm ulcer in the proximal bulb with a necrotic ulcer bed.

The plan includes continuing blood pressure monitoring via arterial line due to the patient's thin body habitus, administration of intravenous pantoprazole (PPI) for stress ulcer prophylaxis, and close monitoring of hematocrit levels every four hours. The patient will remain NPO until 4pm, followed by a clear liquid diet over the weekend if stable. A repeat EGD is planned for Monday in the endoscopy unit after further stabilization. The patient is also being evaluated for potential microperforation given the presence of fever, with a CT scan ordered to assess.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening anemia, infection (due to immunosuppression and risk of aspiration), gastrointestinal bleeding, respiratory complications (such as pneumonia), and renal dysfunction.
